intro: Lipocarpha pygmaea, commonly known as the dwarf spikerush, is a small herbaceous plant native to the wetlands of southern Africa. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant is characterized by its dense clusters of tiny, pale yellow to brown flowers that bloom in late summer. Lipocarpha pygmaea typically grows in shallow water or damp soil, forming low, compact tufts. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, contributing to soil stabilization and habitat for various aquatic organisms.
